DataElement.preferredDefinition: the clinical M (metastasis) stage for an esophageal tumor, as defined by the AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, 7th Ed.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to clinical evaluated M stage of or relating to the esophagus.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to the esophagus.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: Of or relating to the esophagus.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Having to do with the examination and treatment of patients.:One criteria of the TMN staging system.  M refers to the presence of metastasis.

Concepts.definition: Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.origin: AJCC:American Joint Committee on Cancer Cancer Staging Manual, 6th Ed., 2002
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 9/24/18 tt received permission for ownership transfer from CTEP to NCI Standards/BC.

ValueDomain.preferredName: American Joint Committee on Cancer V7 Esophageal Tumor Clinical M Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the clinical M (metastasis) stage for an esophageal tumor, as defined by the AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, 7th Ed.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Refers to cancer that has spread from the original (primary) tumor to distant organs or distant lymph nodes.

Concepts.definition: A biological process that involves the transfer and growth of cancer cells from the site of the primary tumor. Relocation of malignant cells during metastasis can be restricted to movement within a specific tissue/organ or may entail migration to a distal locus within the body. This phenotype is a characteristic of all malignant tumors.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No clinical or radiographic evidence of distant metastases

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: American Joint Committee on Cancer Stage
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.
The extent of a cancer in the body.

ValueDomain.origin: AJCC:American Joint Committee on Cancer Cancer Staging Manual, 7th Ed., 2009

DataElement.origin: AJCC:American Joint Committee on Cancer Cancer Staging Manual, 7th Ed., 2009
